div.head: THE GUAHIBI MOTHER.
div.p:
In 1797, the missionary of San
Fernando had led his Indians to the
banks of the Rio Guaviare, on one of
those hostile occasions, which are pro-
hibited alike by religion and the Spanish
laws. They found, in an ItalianIndian hut,
a Guahibi mother with three children,
two of whom were still infants. They
were occupied in preparing the flour of
Cassava. Resistance was impossible;
the father was gone to fish, the unhap-
py mother tried in vain to flee with her
children. Scarcely had she reached the
Savannah, when seeshe was seized by the
Indians of the mission, who hunt men
with the ferocity of the whites and
the negroes in Africa. The wretched
mother and her children were bound,
and dragged to the bank of the river.
The monk, seated in his boat, waited
the issue of this expedition of barba-
rity, and of which he partook not the
danger. Had the mother made too
violent a resistance, the Indians would
unquestionably have killed her, for any
excess is permitted them when they go
to the conquest of souls, as they term
it (a la conquista espiritual), and it is
children whom they particularly seek
to capture, in order to treat them, in
the mission, as poitos, or slaves of the
Christians. The prisoners were carried
to San Fernando, in the hope that, in
the event of escape, the mother would
be unable to find her way back to her
house by land.

Far from those children who had
accompanied their father on the day
on which she had been carried off,
this unhappy woman shewed signs of
the deepest despair. She attempted to
take back to her family the children
who had been thus brutally snatched
away by the missionary, and fled with
them repeatedly from the village of
San Fernando: but the Indians never
failed to seize her anew; and the mis-
sionary, after having caused the poor
wretch to be mercilessly beaten, took
the cruel resolution of separating the
mother from the two children, who
had been carried off with her. She
was now conveyed alone toward the
mission of the Rio Negro, going up
the river Atabapo; slightly bound, she
was seated at the bow of the boat,
utterly ignorant of the fate that awaited
her; but she judged, by the direction
of the sun, that she was removed far-
ther and farther from her hut and her
native country. Seizing a favourable
opportunity, she succeeded in breaking
her bonds, threw herself into the wa-
ter, and swam to the left bank of the
river. The current carried her to a
shelf of rock, which bears her name
to this day. Here she landed, and
took shelter in the woods: but the
president of the missions, astonished
at her courage, ordered his Indians to
row to the shore, and followed the
traces of the Guahibi. In the evening
the unhappy creature was brought
back. Stretched upon the rock, still
called (la piedra de la Madre), a cruel
punishment was inflicted on her with
those straps of manatee leather which
serve for whips in that country, and
with which the Alcades are always
furnished; and the unhappy woman,
her hands tied behind her back with
strong stalks of mavacure, was then
dragged to the mission of Javita.

She was there thrown into one of
the caravanseras that are called Casa
del Rey. It was during the rainy
season, when the night was profoundly
dark; forests, till then, believed to be
impenetrable, separated the mission of
Javita from that of San Fernando,
the nearest distance to which was
twenty-five leagues in a straight line.
No other part of the country is known,
but the course of the rivers; nor does
any man ever attempt to go by land
from one village to another, were they
only a few leagues apart. But what
difficulties shall stay a mother, who is
separated from her children? The
children of this devoted and coura-
geous woman are at San Fernando de
Atabapo; nature cries out, inciting
her to find them again; she conceives
the possibility of executing her project
of delivering them from the hands of
Christians, and of bringing them back
to their father on the banks of the
Guaviare. The Guahibi was carelessly
guarded in the caravansera. Her arms
being wounded, the Indians of Javita
had loosened her bonds, unknown to
the missionary and the Alcades. She
succeeded, by the help of her teeth,
in breaking them entirely; disappeared
during the night; and at the fourth
rising sun had actually arrived at the
mission of San Fernando, and was seen
hovering around the hut where her
children were confined. “What that
wonderful woman performed,” added
the missionary, who gave us this sad
narrative, “the most robust Indian
would not have ventured to undertake.
She traversed the woods at a season
when the sky is constantly covered
with clouds, and the sun during whole
days appears but for a few minutes.
The course of the waters affords her
no indication by which to direct her
way! The inundations of the rivers
forced her to go far from the banks of
the main stream, through the midst of
woods, where the movement of the
waters is almost imperceptible. How
often must she have been stopped by
the thorny lianas, that from a net-work
around the trunks they entwine? How
often must she have swam across the
rivulets that run into the Atabapo? —
This unfortunate woman was asked
how she had sustained herself during
the four days? She replied, that, ex-
hausted with fatigue, she could find
no other nourishment than those great
black ants, called vachacos, which
climb the trees in long bands, to sus-
pend on them their resinous nests!
We pressed the missionary to tell us
whether the Guahibi had, after these
unexampled exertions, been allowed
peaceably to enjoy the happiness of
remaining with her children; and if
any repentance had followed this ex-
cess of cruelty, on the part of her
tormentors? He refused, however, to
satisfy our curiosity; but at our re-
turn from the Rio Negro, we learnt,
that the Indian mother had not even
been allowed time to cure her wounds,
but was again separated from her chil-
dren, and sent to one of the missions
of the Upper Oroonoko, where death
afforded her a kind release from her
anxieties and sufferings. It appeared
that the unfortunate creature had, at
length, as is the custom with all savage
tribes in cases of overbearing calamity,
accelerated the approach of death, by
refusing all nourishment.
